comment: If you have 40-200 kids, it's not a homeschool, it's just another for-profit private school.

I wish they had highlighted the many people who homeschool for non-religious and non-political reasons. There are a lot of us out there. My kids are awesome people. I enjoy spending time with them and allowing them the freedom to learn based on their interests and in a way they respond best. Sometimes homeschooling isn‚Äôt about making any religious or political statement; it‚Äôs about loving your children and desiring them to reach their best potential.

I was homeschooled, but my mother is a qualified educator. She was/is a teacher, a curriculum developer and was a deputy superintendent..We got an education that was almost on par with standard public school. So by the time we transitioned to public high school, we were able to just slide right on in..B U T..She never homeschooled us for a political/religious/conspiratorial reason.It was simply because the school on the Reservation I grew up on didn't have quality education. She got sick of the GENUINE educational neglect, and decided to take things into her own hands..These guys aren't even educated themselves ü§£
The greatest challenge of this world is knowing enough about a subject to think you are right, but not knowing enough about the subject to know you are wrong‚Ä¶

I was homeschooled till grade 6, and it was amazing. I would be done my schoolwork by noon, and be outside playing till dinner every day. We had 3 month long summers because we were able to finish our semesters early, due to there being 3 kids for 1 teacher instead of 30 kids..We've expressed interest about homeschooling our kids to friends and family, reason being that we could give them a similar upbringing, not be tied down to a rigid schedule, or one place..But most of the people we've told get excited and start talking about how 'the world is getting so crazy nowadays', and I know they're excited because of the same reasons the people in this documentary have..Makes me feel gross knowing these people think I share their delusions about conspiracies and religious fervor, I just want my family to have a rad life

There needs to be 10 year follow up video on these kids to see how they fared post-home school. I have a feeling it won‚Äôt turn out all that well. Most in this video are being home schooled for all the wrong reasons. If you have a good reason, it will stand up to criticism rather than retreating to their bubble.

I have two sons, one in his early 30s and one in his early twenties. Both of them were home schooled for part of their education but not all of it. It was because I live in rural Virginia and the schools are much more regressive than the schools in Seattle where I moved from. There were a lot of discipline problems when my older son was in school, so he did middle school homeschooled and then went back to school for high school. My younger son is on the autism spectrum so I pulled him out after 6th grade and he finished school homeschooled. It was their choice, we did secular homeschooling, we did a lot of co-ops so they were around other children and I saw a lot of things that scared me. In the state where I live you can declare homeschooling for religious reasons and never have to show a test result. I saw kids that were woefully ignorant of common knowledge and I also saw two different occasions of abusers who didn't want their kids in school because counselors were asking too many questions. I think it's disgusting how children's education has been co-opted by the fear mongerers. at the very least someone who's homeschooling should have to test their child and they should have to pass a basic test for knowledge for their age.

I think a lot of patents who had to help their kids with virtual learning during the pandemic realized they are capable of homeschooling. I think it's important to realize people pulling their kids out of public school is a symptom that public education in the USA is seriously flawed.

I am a homeschooling parent. Not all homeschoolers are as politically driven as some of these people being interviewed. In fact, I wish it wasn‚Äôt portrayed as such a political weapon rather than a powerful tool in a child‚Äôs education. Homeschoolers can learn and move through curriculum at their own pace. They normally excel because they don‚Äôt have to compete with a large classroom for individualized instruction that fits their academic needs. I also love that I can teach my children more about their culture. At the same time I think it can be a disservice for the ones who pull their kids and decide to not teach them about other cultures all in the name of ‚ÄúCRT‚Äù (which is not taught in schools k-12 btw). Homeschooling is a powerful tool and as mentioned I will fight for my right to homeschool because I know that it is what is best for my children. But I don‚Äôt have the same reasons as some of these people. It actually makes me annoyed to hear these people pushing their political agendas on to these children. In my homeschool I teach my children. As they grow older and learn about politics they can decide their own political stance.

My Mom homeschooled me due to the fact that I had a learning Disability and the Public Schools didn't want to take the time to properly teach me,so they tried to sweep me under the Rug and pretend I didn't exist until she pulled me out and Taught me herself. I loved it! I was able to get the one on one teaching I NEEDED,I did other programs with other homeschooled children who later became my friends twice a week,I began to excel once we found a method that actually worked for me. I was always and will always be so grateful to my Parents for doing what they did,I wouldn't have changed a thing. I'm in my early 30's now,I graduated College,became a Welder for 3 years,a warehouse manager for 2,a CNA for 2 and now run my own Business. Homeschool is such an amazing tool for your child if done RIGHT.

I was homeschooled and loved it and plan on doing it for my kids. I've done extraordinarily well for myself and experienced first hand the benefits of the flexibility/1:1 to accommodate my apd. But I want to make something clear: the real dangers of homeschooling are parents who homeschool for non-educational reasons (crt, religion, political). However, as far as education goes, if done right, it is arguably better because you get a more customized curriculum for that student needs/strengths/weaknesses.

It will be interesting to see the advanced level of education that these non teachers provide.  For the kids sake I truly hope their experiment sets these and others up for a life of success.  Personally, Finland has the highest quality of education in the world and everyone attends public schools.  Not to mention the economic privilege that people have to even consider a homeschool option.

As a homeschool alum, homeschooling *can* be great. It *can* be very helpful for a lot of children. But the reality is that a significant number of parents neglect their children's education and/or use homeschooling as an excuse to control and abuse their children. None of my siblings (myself included) received an adequate education and those still under 18 live in a high-control environment with little freedom.

I was homeschooled. I've been on both sides of the fence. Private school for elementary, homeschooled for middle school and most of high school and now community college. There are pros and cons to all types of education. Don't pick a side. Stay cultured. Have convictions. Explore. Try things. Love people. This is what grows good people. Not just books or the building. The school of life is my favorite.

As a child I was a shy kid with immigrant parents who did t speak English, i struggled and thought that I was stupid , the teachers and staff wouldn‚Äôt pay attention to me as much and would give me a little extra time teaching me . I asked but was ignored. As an adult I find that I wasn‚Äôt stupid but the environment I was in at school made hard for me to grow and made me even more shy at as a teenager. My choice to homeschool my girls at least for primary school was based on my experience. I want to make sure my girls grow on their pace and not feel discouraged but build confidence.

I was home schooled for grades 9 to 12 here in Canada. It was almost exactly like school, except I could do as much or as little a day. As long as I did all the tests and had the courses finished by end of year. Up here at least, home schooling just means from home. Learn the same things as those in school..This is insanity.

I was homeschooled for a few years and skipped a grade and finished in public school. It's crazy how much better you can learn with homeschool. Most of my cousins were homeschooled and they all have university degrees and are insanely interesting as they have a huge capacity for critical thought. Religion aside, it is not hard for homeschool to be superior academically.

The teacher who almost started crying earlier in her interview and then started crying about not being able to buy her personal books, shows how stressed out teachers are and how broken this system is.  I am worry about the mental health of public school teachers, if this is what comes out during an interview about being a public school teacher... Maybe, taking kids out of the home, away from their families, maybe  taking parents away from their children to be raised by others isn't a great system. We took a potential great thing and used it and abused it. Public education was never supposed to replace the family, it was supposed to help it. ..I'm frustrated by the way this was framed. Do you know how much money is lost to families who homeschool? They do not stop paying taxes to the school system. All books, and all curriculum has to be bought by the family. The potential for an entire income is lost. Please stop framing it as if homeschool families are taking something away financial from the system. They're not. Homeschooling puts them at a great financial disadvantage. but apparently, it's worth it.

I was homeschooled in Texas but both of my parents are college educated. I used to work with my mom and then I started taking classes with other homeschoolers once a week. Honestly, it was like a college. I loved it and wouldn‚Äôt have changed it for anything. I graduated from college, moved abroad, and now speak three languages. I was educated but I certainly know other ‚Äúhomeschoolers‚Äù that didn‚Äôt actually study. Politics don‚Äôt belong in the education system and I truly believe that more people would stay if they believed that.

I was homeschooled k-12, and while I personally have been able to achieve decent academic success, the negative social impact is not at all worth it. If you homeschool, there is a very high chance you are setting your children up for severe emotional and social dysfunction. Also, homeschooling leads children up having gaps in their education. I grew up thinking I was fundamentally terrible at math. I went to college and found out I was actually rather good at it. My parents were just bad at teaching it. There will just always be blind spots like this, even if the parents involved are not actively indoctrinating their children into Christian nationalism.  It's just a bad idea.

I was ‚Äúunschooled‚Äù as a kid, which is an extreme form of homeschooling where I was allowed to do literally whatever I wanted every day with no curriculum of any kind. .My parents chose this just because we lived in the country far from school, not for any religious reasons. .It sounds like a crazy way to do school, but what I realized once I got to college (and got a 4.0 gpa my very first semester) is that going to a traditional school is really not important for academic success. Same once I entered the workforce and realized that being able to read and learn things on your own, think logically and creatively, and be resourceful are much more important. 10 years later and I‚Äôm happily married with kids, living a pretty typical life. ..What I‚Äôm trying to say, I guess, is that there is no right or wrong way to do school. I think that parents and the support they give to their kids is way more important, whether the kids are going to school or staying at home

I was an online student in AZVA-K12 system in Arizona from 2010-2015. Aside from half of 8th and all of 9th, I was in online school from 7th grade onward. These systems are garbage. If you're already upset about the fact that public schools overwhelmingly care about having butts in seats for attendance money over actual education, I assure you online school is far worse. My dad used me to get government support and child support checks from my mom, and the school used me for their attendance stats. I was fully responsible and the teachers knew it. I did the work, then logged in as the parent account to input attendance then log right back out. What did they have a problem with in this situation? The fact that I was putting the real time it takes to get through their lessons, 15-20 minutes, and they wanted me to put an hour for each class regardless. They even set it up so that if you click to input your time, it always defaults to an hour so you can literally just click down the list and hit "send". When my grades started slipping because obviously a depressed, socially isolated teenager isn't going to play along with this obvious bullshit system, they would call ME to issue ultimatums about my grades and assignments. The only calls the PARENT got was to ask to speak to me about it. I even have one of the voicemails they left him because he emailed it to me like I'm an employee...The "benefit" of homeschooling can only be reaped by rich white Christians where the daddy has a well paying job handed to him and mommy stays at home. Funny how it also benefits Christians by allowing them to indoctrinate their kids better. It's almost as if homeschooling is being pushed because even private school isn't insulating enough against reality for christians.

Ah I have a lot to say on this! I was homeschooled in Montana my whole life without ever going to a school, I'm 34 now for context. I come from a large family and there are a lot of homeschoolers in my community who also have large families. Were predominantly a mix of protestant and Mormon faiths. Everyone's primary reason for homeschooling was religion. That said, some are more extreme the others. For instance; my family was super strict on some things, and very loose on others. All the homeschoolers in my area are self-employed as pastors, tradesmen, accountants, or farmers/ranchers. ..There were two types of homeschoolers: the dedicated to education/spelling bee ones who typically go on to super successful lives post college, and the ones who skip college to enter the family business full time...Many homeschoolers are enrolled at least part-time in their local community colleges by the time they're in high-school to help learn subjects their parents aren't qualified to teach. This means by the time they graduate high-school and transition to college, they're more prepared than the average private or public school student. Additionally, working with our families in business during childhood teaches us a lot of things many other kids wouldn't know - strong work ethics, practical knowledge of a trade, and a taste of what adulthood looks like...Homeschooling can either be the greatest thing for a child because they can receive more time and training in school, putting them ahead of their public and private school peers, or it can be the worst thing if they are smothered with religion and don't receive even a basic education...I'm an engineer, another sibling is an engineer, another sibling is a mathematician, others are working the family business, so my family has been very successful partially as a result of homeschooling, and partially because my parents were smart enough to keep religion out of our education. We all have multiple degrees and value learning..The problem is with the mainstream homeschoolers who have crazy ideas about religion to the point of clinical insanity...Homeschooling has perhaps the *greatest* potential amongst all the learning types because of the amount of time, attention, and creativity a parent or teacher can provide to the student. That said, many fall flat as a result of misguided faith and religion...Also, I should note, my family was considered lower middle class, some families are near poverty level - for those saying only privlieged families can homeschool.

Teacher here agreeing our students, families, and teachers need more support. One piece that would be very interesting is to look into districts budgeting. Looking into the shortage of teachers would give an interesting perspective as well. ..I believe our education system is a reflection of our society. Our schools are a reflection of our community and values...Teaching can be very rewarding but also life sucking. Teachers could put 100% into their craft or do the bare minimum. ..I can‚Äôt help but bring up safety. Reality, most us do not feel safe in public areas. Our solutions there are exact opposite. If we cannot agree on how to keep our babies safe in a classroom we are definitely not ready to discuss learning curriculums or lack there of them. ..Praying for our future. üòÖ

I was home schooled in grade 6 and I love my parents but that was one of the worst things I experienced in regards to my education. Neither of them were equipped enough to teach their children properly and I am so glad their surrounding friends and family convinced them to bring me back to school by the second term of that year. I was so behind and so isolated while getting homeschooled and when I came back, I managed to catch up thanks to the teacher's assistants working in that institution. These parents have no idea what they are depriving their children, politics or not these kids are not going to grow up as functional adults in society. Not unless they live the rest of their lives in a far right conservative bunker.

I was home schooled growing up in Canada up until grade 8. It was nothing like these conspiratorial nut jobs... it wasn't perfect, but we had curriculum, tests, grades, etc. This is just insanity...

I feel like the homeschool outdoor school might not have the highest quality of lessons but as a teacher I still feel that the type of education that they offer with the mix of physical activities and learning would be benificial to quite a lot of students
I think the idea of letting kids do more kinesthetic activities is very smart. I'm a kinesthetic learner and I wish I had more of a hands on/ working with my hands education.

Teachers should be paid as much as doctors and lawyers and respected as such in a modern society. With the same level of credential requirements..Teachers are fundamentally important to our society and it sucks that they are so terribly treated.

I was homeschooled all the way back in the 90‚Äôs when it really wasn‚Äôt common, except for religious reasons. By the time I got into high school, I was taking some courses at one of the local universities by me, and actually getting college credits for it! I performed really well on my SAT & ACTs and got into college. I went on to end up getting 2 degrees, and a masters, masters in nursing, which is no cake walk. ..While there are ppl like the ones in this video who are really into homeschooling for various reasons, as well as a lot of religious reasons, there are a lot of homeschoolers out there who even though they may come from a family that does have a religion (I am Catholic for example, but my religion played no part in me homeschooling), they‚Äôre not specifically homeschooling for those reasons and their kids are getting an excellent education - one much better than they would have been able to get in public schools. ..I really wish documentaries would actually include focusing on those families and kids! I see many other commenters in this comment section saying they were homeschooled as well and this video doesn‚Äôt represent what their experience was like! It‚Äôs just so tiring. Every documentary or video on homeschooling has always focuses on the religious, political or more radical reasons ppl homeschool, their families and aspects of homeschooling. It‚Äôs insane that I was dealing w that representation of ‚Äúthis is what homeschooling is and it‚Äôs so dangerous!‚Äù In the 90‚Äôs and now here we are 30 years later and it‚Äôs still being represented that way! Sheesh.

In the 90‚Äôs the homeschooling critics said, ‚ÄúWe can‚Äôt let family‚Äôs homeschool because children can‚Äôt learn of they don‚Äôt have a certified teacher. They won‚Äôt get a decent education like in the public system.‚Äù Now that homeschoolers have been kicking the intellectual rear ends of their public school peers for many years, the new excuse is, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs unfair that some kids can homeschool because they get one on one attention. Of course they‚Äôre going to perform better!‚Äù  Lol, make up your minds.

I‚Äôve been homeschooled for my whole life and one of my parents reasons was so that me and my sisters could figure out what I wanted to do in life. I have seen in my life how this has effected me and one thing is that as a 15 year old I can think for myself, I have my own money, I have been able to volunteer for my community even in the middle of the week

I was homeschooled because my parents didn‚Äôt trust the quality of our local public school which was known for bullying and drug use. My mom is a qualified teacher and i really appreciate that she gave so much of her time for her kids, when other parents would understandably prefer to take back some of that free time back.

As a teacher, like with any system, there are pros and cons...Under ideal circumstances, homeschooling would be the ideal. One on one instruction, teaching at their level, and enrichment...However, reality is far more brutal. Sometimes I have students enter the system who have been homeschooled. Within the first few days I quiz them about what they were learning about or where they left off, in the hopes of building continuity in their education. And the answer? "I wasn't learning anything." or "I haven't been in school for X years"...It is sad how often it occurs, and all I can do is help them while I have them. However fleeting that is.

For years Before the pandemic I ran a homeschool gardening / nature school from my home with an amazing small group of home birthing, freethinking, caring parents. This video is a different angle on homeschooling very politically/ religiously driven. I was a public school teacher for over 10 years but working with the hippy dippy freethinking, life living, family and nature oriented homeschool community changed my life . In my mind that is ‚Äúhomeschool‚Äù.

I say this as a teacher- homeschool is honestly a good way to go as long as you have a proper curriculum helping you out. I've had a class of more than 40 students. It's not possible for me to help them all in the ways that they each need. ..However, I do believe if kids are not being taught my licensed teacher, the state really should be testing them, just to make sure the kids are actually learning something. I've seen too many horror stories of kids coming to school thinking the earth is flat and dinosaurs are fake and not being able to read at all.

I wasn‚Äôt homeschooled but when I was transferring schools my mom and I looked into homeschooling me. However it wasn‚Äôt the best option for me due to educational needs. So we explored the private school system and since the schools in my area didn‚Äôt offer educational support services ( special education). we looked at charter but the one and only charter in my area had a waiting list that was long . So we decided a different public school district was the best option. ..Ultimately my mom let me decide what path would be the best for me. I was 13 years old and I knew what I needed academically. Now I‚Äôm in college studying to be a special education teacher ....Edit wanted to add ..When the pandemic hit, the transition to online homeschool for college was a struggle. So I looked towards the youth of my church who were homeschooled and their parents. With their help and I was able to structure a plan that suited me. Those habits transferred with me to on campus learning. I have a deep respect for homeschooled students and their families. I admire them in many ways and somewhat envy them but they taught me ‚Äú I don‚Äôt have to stop learning even when I‚Äôm not in class ‚Äú .

To be fair, if your child is talented and is forced to go to a school where the children are aggressive and violent towards bright kids, it makes sense to homeschool where your child will be safe and not be hindered by the class
This really makes me proud. To see so many parents so passionate about their children‚Äôs education. Anyone who can, should homeschool.

It‚Äôs frustrating that despite homeschooling offering a potential alternative to public schooling, they‚Äôve just made a more sheltered version of summer camp that is wildly subject to the internal biases of their teachers. Honestly they‚Äôve almost reinvented Montessori schools but instead of having highly educated teachers they have just regular people

Mixed opinion on this, the kids I knew who were homeschooled were way smarter and better educated than the average public school student in my area. Though their parents were pretty bright people. Went to a private school, then a public and was surprised how poor quality the education was comparatively and met formerly homeschooled kids who felt the same. Conflicted in the part that I met lifelong friends in public school, including that formerly homeschooled friend. It seems public school is better for socialization and homeschool is often better for education.

I was homeschooled pretty much throughout grade school. My mother worked and homeschooled 7 children. During freshman year I did go to a public high school and after school, I would babysit while my mother went to work. I finished the year with all A's and didn't want to go back. I could see the lack of parenting and real-world education many of my peers desperately needed. I went back to homeschooling and sophomore year did dual enrollment at the technical college which I enjoyed a bit better. My parents gave up a lot to give all seven of us the education and family life we had. I count myself very lucky and I encourage everyone to homeschool their kids.

I was self educated; not homeschooled. Public middle school and high school was a joke; it was a punishment; it was a glorified day care for big kids; a place to learn how to do drugs and develop new pathologies. Elementary school was ok back in the 90s, but now it's very ideological. Kids in my district don't even call their teachers Mr. and Mrs. -- they call them by their first name. I don't think people realize how public school has changed since they were in school. They don't even teach phonics any more!!! Kids are graduating from hs that can't even read.

I grew up in public schools. Honestly the lack of funding is the worst part. My high school had temporary roofs that hadn‚Äôt been fixed in 10 years from a hurricane. Which led to it leaking over the summer, destroying textbooks, and there not being enough books to go around. My little sister is 12 years younger than me and is in charter school. Its way better funding, teachers actually look happy to teach, but honestly the people there are the same people I met in public school so theres no difference there. My parents make more money now so they can afford the charter school, but I can imagine how hard it can be to put your child in charter school of you dont make a lot of money. Honestly the more we move away from public schools, has me scared that once again the poor will not have a right to be educated as others. It creates a cycle of being poor. I was always the smartest person in class in my public school but when I went off to college I saw the better quality of education that other people were getting at other schools. My public schools never assigned homework on computer (like math homework done solely on computers), when I went to college everyone had done that for years, and I was stuck learning how to do math on a computer. The problem should be to fund the public schools not take away funding

I think the key here is that schooling should be about child development and NOT about parental beliefs. If i choose to teach my son solely on what I believe, he is then limited to only knowing what I choose and how I choose to teach him. I believe that public/private/home schooling should work hand and hand to create a holisic environment of learning. I talk ALOT with my sons teacher, I am a home room parent, and I work full time. We work TOGETHER to give my son the tools he needs to grasp concepts. I have gotten great tips from his teacher to use at home and I have made useful suggestions to his teacher to improve his experience at school. ..We need to stop thinking that kids only learn in school. I think that public schools will need to stop focusing on scores and tests, and work closely with parents and Home and School Associations to create the complete environment each child needs to grow. If you just drop your child off at a building and expect the teacher to do everything, your child will not benefit, and I honestly believe, that if you teach your child at home how you WANT to teach them, and not how they learn best, your child will also not benefit.

I was homeschooled up to high school because I lived in a terrible area. The schools were violent, even in the younger grades, and weren‚Äôt a great learning environment. From a social standpoint, I hated it, but I got to high school and felt way ahead of my peers. Also, it should be said my mom had to get her GED. She didn‚Äôt do well in school but she followed the curriculum and used videos as well as other teachers to give me the education opportunities she didn‚Äôt have.

I've experienced the formal school, private boarding school, and homeschool. For me, who has trouble focusing to something (mostly in a crowded room), homeschool rlly helped me. I do homeschool for the entire highschool. My parents are both top university graduate and my mother even have a master degree in children psychology. I'm blessed with private teacher, great source, great parents, just like school but more suitable for me. My studying has become more efficient and this has made me fell in love with studying. I can learn like normal kids my age and even surpass my friends from both the formal school and homeschool (in terms of grades and subjects, and i was strictly prohibited from cheating), doing my passion and hobbies, getting closer with my family. And surprisingly, not to be a narcissist or whatever, through homeschool i became more independent, more mature than kids my age, knowing and understanding myself more, and understanding of how things work in real life, which if without homeschool, i doubt i would be the person i am rn. Homeschool may not be for everyone but for me it's a blessing...So i think just found what suits you best would be the best option since none of us are the same.

honestly i think that going to public school shaped me well. to be around different people from different backgrounds taught me more than i can even say. you'll always be around people you disagree with(or agree with). to learn how to adapt and become a worthwhile person in youth is vital. I may not agree with everything in public schools but thats the point.

My kids attend a school similar this.  It‚Äôs sometimes called the college model.  They spend two days at school doing their core subjects and the other days at home.  They still do academics at home (when you break the average public school day down it‚Äôs about 2 hours of academic learning).  ..Both my kids read 2 grade levels above their grade, and score above average on state tests on math and English.  They also have the flexibility to pursue their passions and interests.   My daughter is a level 8 gymnast and doesn‚Äôt have to be gone all the time as she trains 20 hours a week in the gym.  My son gets to go to his music lessons in the mornings and advance and compete in piano beyond what he would learn on a recording for a year in public school. ..We get plenty of family time because my husband works from home.  We will never go back to public school.

My kids attend a school similar this.  It‚Äôs sometimes called the college model.  They spend two days at school doing their core subjects and the other days at home.  They still do academics at home (when you break the average public school day down it‚Äôs about 2 hours of academic learning).  ..Both my kids read 2 grade levels above their grade, and score above average on state tests on math and English.  They also have the flexibility to pursue their passions and interests.   My daughter is a level 8 gymnast and doesn‚Äôt have to be gone all the time as she trains 20 hours a week in the gym.  My son gets to go to his music lessons in the mornings and advance and compete in piano beyond what he would learn on a recording for a year in public school. ..We get plenty of family time because my husband works from home.  We will never go back to public school.

We homeschooled my nephew during the pandemic because he was behind in English and online schooling didn't work for him.  (He dropped from A/B to F.)  For us it was a combination of keeping him safe from Covid and minimizing stress (we had a house fire before the pandemic and he had to move 5 times).  He's older now, so we're trying a dedicated public online school to ease him back in.   The stereotype is that homeschooling is done for religious or political reasons, but sometimes it's just about responding to practical needs, educational or life...Thankfully local government is pretty chill about it.  We're in a good area to be homeschoolers.

I was homeschooled and so we‚Äôre my three sisters. I grew up with it. As and adult I realize how much I missed and how much I never learned because the state didn‚Äôt hold anyone accountable. The amount of educational loss in the community is overwhelming. Also parentification and losing your future for a lotttttt of homeschool families. Especially the religious and fundamentalist ones like the ones I grew up around. There are some upsides but as a whole I think it does more harm than good

Our daughter suffered from extreme anxiety starting in 8th grade. Starting in highschool, she started going to public school remotely through the K12 program. It was a God send...What a blessing to not only have something she could excel in, but not worry about school shootings. ..Side note: when COVID hit, it was just another day of school. I told her she's going to have a leg up on all her peers because they never missed a day from school and already had curriculum tailored for remote learning with teachers experienced in remote teaching. My daughter is now in college studying to be a Physician's Assistant.

There are a lot of comments about the positive and wholesome homeschooling experiences that people have had in their lives. That is truly wonderful, but it's not the story for everyone. ..My best friend was homeschooled by her parents until she renrolled in high school. She was overwhelmed and struggled immensely in high school and the "real" world outside of her home. She was raised in a very isolated environment with parents who barely knew math, science, or grammar, and when she finally joined public school, she struggled immensely just to keep up and had to relearn almost everything on her own. She wasn't the only former homeschool kid I knew in high school who faced a lot of issues. Although not all of them struggled, most had emotional, social, and academic problems that followed them into college and beyond. I think it's important to remember that while most of the parents in this video are bright and responsible people that provide ample, positive education for their children, there are also many homeschool parents who lack education and awareness and are not actually capable of providing a proper and applicable education to their children. Unrestricted and unregulated homeschooling can give some parents the ability to isolate and control their children, causing only harm and doing minimal good. ..Not to mention the fact that here in rural Indiana, the majority of homeschoolers are indoctrinated hardcore into Christianity, which isn't inherently bad, but, again, it can cause a lot of awful and traumatizing issues when they finally leave home and go to college, get a job, and start socializing with people who are different from them. ..I can definitely understand the appeal of homeschooling, especially nowadays, but it is also far from a perfect system. Oversight and protections are needed for homeschool kids, too.

It is an easy decision for my family. Home schooling takes far less time, it allows for creative experiences that likely won‚Äôt happen in a restricted environment, and home schooling teaches that learning is happening all the time (not restricted to a set time or place). .It does come at an intentional sacrifice of making less money. Totally worth it.

This should be a series. I home school because the public school system was failing my special needs child. They had such bad experiences there, the trauma so bad, that even changing schools didn't help. My school district has no alternative programs, resulting in my child having no education for over a year. We tried a religious based program that was  racist and xenophobic with no guidance at all. I'm college educated but honestly I am completely inept at sharing what I know. Especially in math. I know of other families who have had to turn to homeschooling because of bullying.

Parents have the right to choose how their children learn and homeschooling is a great option for many. I'm grateful for my homeschool education. It's a beautiful thing to see parents pulling their children out of the corrupt public education system that is failing them and choosing to homeschool.
I feel for the teachers! I hope one day they can get the respect (and pay) that they deserve!‚ù§Ô∏è

One of my kids is homeschooled and my daughter is about to graduate high school at 16 in honors college courses and she has seen the world while doing so. I can say without a doubt she would not be excelling in life at this young of an age in a public school. Comparatively to my child in public and others in my life, the knowledge, introspection and well rounded intellect just don't match up. If you do this for the proper reasons, I truly believe it is far superior to most public schools today. Plus your children stay closer to you and and their family due to not being away for 8 hours a day where they learn less. For example, with information at our finger tips and access to literature, there are more efficient methods to absorb and apply information than text books and classrooms with 20 plus peers.

My brother home schooled his kids with his wife to shelter them, and conserve their Christian ideals, but people forget, kids rebel. They may not at first, but they do eventually. A decent amount of freedom is more powerful than isolation, always. Kids need to know about drugs, different ideas and ideals and most importantly they need to know about who they are, and they can only do that through interactions.

I homeschooled because I wanted my kids to see their father more. I'm not religious at all and love teaching my kids about the real things that people are trying to block. Teach them about segregation and the truth. I love that my kids can be hands on and we can learn about things at any time of the day when we come across opportunities. I homeschool my son. The freedom is great, but it‚Äôs also troubling that in some states like mine, there‚Äôs virtually zero (0) standard(s). While I‚Äôm teaching my son, keeping accurate transcripts etc., another parent could not teach a single subject for years on end, and the state would say nothing. I suppose it‚Äôs yet another reason my state lives permanently around last place in education.

I was homeschooled until the second half of third grade. My brother was in second grade and my sister in sixth grade. We were all extremely ahead (like 1-2 years) of our peers. We only had a few hours of schooling a day and went out to play or read or whatever we wanted the rest of the time. My mom taught us and did not have a college degree or excel when she was in school herself. The programs created for homeschooling do a very good job of fostering independent learning. We did lots of sports and went to church and had neighbor kids to play with, for socialization. The drawbacks were some social struggling when starting school because kids learn to be so damned mean at school! We were kind and empathetic kids who stood up for the bullied and disabled kids. It was really hard for us to see kids be so mean, and hard when they were mean to us.

I agree with this video that sometimes homeschooling can be done improperly and that the motivations of parents may not always be perfect. However, homeschooling can be wonderful for many families! I grew up homeschooled along with my four sisters through all of elementary, middle, and high school. All of my sisters and I got way above average scores on the ACT (mine was a 29, my older sisters‚Äô were 28 and 30. I don‚Äôt know my younger sister‚Äôs score). And for the three of us who decided to go to college, my oldest sister and I who have bachelors degrees graduated with highest honors and differing baccalaureate awards and my little sister is currently getting her associates degree and getting all A‚Äôs. People are so worried that homeschoolers won‚Äôt be able to succeed in life, but I always am frustrated by this because there are so many public schoolers who aren‚Äôt succeeding and nobody ever brings up that. All of my friends were all local kids who either went to public or private schools and I remember them coming over to play and begging my mom to homeschool them too because they saw how much fun we were having while learning and that we were actually able to learn and explore and grow as individuals. Which isn‚Äôt something that all public schoolers are able to easily do in a public school environment when an underpaid and overworked teacher has his/her attention divided amongst 20+ kids and about 50% of class time is simply spent on behavioral management. Not knocking public schools, I just think we need to be honest about how the public education system in America currently sucks (and, yes, deserves more funding) and not start to shift the blame for that onto parents who have simply recognized that and then choose to privatize their kids‚Äô education for their kids‚Äô benefit.

I was homeschooled K-12 and absolutely loved it. My education was far more rigorous and thorough than my public school peers, my social life (with homeschoolers and non-homeschoolers) was vibrant, the life skills I developed eqipped me well for college and a career, and the flexibility allowed me to pursue my interests and mature into a prepared adult. I am forever grateful to my parents for not settling for the public school options available. The public school district, who I now work for, is nearly the worst in the nation and hovered low on the list since before I was born. To suggest that parents should keep their kids in their local district and just fix the problems is a nearly comical oversimplification of the what is broken in our school system. There are serious and understandable concerns on both sides of this debate. I would like to have seen them addressed in more depth on each.

I was homeschooled k-12, in some areas I excelled academically, but some things were a real struggle, especially around math. The way my dad explained math didn't always make sense and I would get really confused. I feel like I would have benefited from a teacher that had a deeper understanding of the content as well as multiple teaching styles to help different types of learners. ..My parents homeschooled for religious reasons, so my education was half Bible study and half actual learning content. The way they would teach science and always tack on "and that's how God made it" to anything that might seem to support evolution, or how every piece of history was twisted to support colonialism and white Christian nationalism. It has been a very concerted effort on my part as an adult to correct those things in my mind.

Besides the lacking diversity the main bottleneck of homeschooling in my POV is the lack of social interaction. Working in groups is a major part in (at least German) school life. Dealing with different mindsets and work-ethics when it comes to group projects is an important experience when it comes to social interaction.

I want to point out that many of these programs that look like really good ‚Äúhomeschooling‚Äù programs are really closer to a camp than traditional homeschooling. In fact with all the kids walking around in a building with backpacks, learning from people who aren‚Äôt their parents, it almost looks like a school. ..Point is maybe what we need more so is large scale reform in our educational system, rather than homeschooling. The problem isn‚Äôt necessarily schools, it‚Äôs that our education system sucks. Which is nothing new, yet for some reason it‚Äôs focused more on ‚Äúschool vs homeschoolers‚Äù rather than ‚Äútraditional schooling vs reformed schooling‚Äù.

I was recently asked to teach some home schooled kids. My background is biology. I charge 30/hr. Ive worked in the classroom and it's a mess. I don't blame anyone for wanting to homeschool their kid. I also don't blame any teacher for wanting to leave the classroom.

I would never have considered homeschooling were it not for the deplorable state of our public schools at the time but I'm sure glad we did it. I hate to imagine how their lives would have turned out had we not done so. And OMG! We had so much fun doing it.

‚ÄúPlay is a child‚Äôs work.‚Äù This is what we live by. Ironically, I began homeschooling just prior to the pandemic. It was due to my then 6 year old finding it impossible to adapt, and feel safe in the charter school chaos. He was anxious, and learning nothing. His behavior at home began to decline. The teacher he began with left for maternity leave, never returning. Replaced by a revolving door of substitutes that were not accustomed to younger students. The lack of consistency was counterintuitive. Then there was the long day, removal of outside recess as a means of discipline. The list goes on. His poor teacher would often get back to us at 11pm claiming to have just gotten home from school that late in the evening. My infant at the time got sick and hospitalized from the constant illnesses that my older child was carrying home too. We do know that there are detrimental effects of masking the faces of young children in terms of language, psychological, and emotional development. With very little proof of efficacy. As soon as these masked kids would settle to eat lunch, the masks are removed lol. It‚Äôs such nonsense. We don‚Äôt homeschool due to that or politics/religion. We homeschool because my child learns best when he feels safe, and when the curriculum can be tailored for his specific learning style. Once he was recovered from the trauma of his conventional school experienced, I could not have been√Ø prouder of how beautifully he has acclimated. He is mature, responsible, takes accountability, is kind, and he reads constantly for enjoyment. I think homeschooled kids are going go change their generations future.

My wife and I just started HS homeschooling this week. 2/20/23.Best choice because our public School System is broken and teaching Garbage. Props to this Man in the video for starting this program up. I don‚Äôt know him but Thank you Sir. Good Documentaryüëçüèº

I was homeschooled most of my time growing up because whenever we would try putting me in a public or private school, I was not learning. I wasn't understanding anything because they were not teaching me in ways I could understand. And it didn't help that I was chronically ill and disabled and the schools refused to give me any accommodations. Heck, my local public school put me on homebound and sent teachers, but literally said to my parents' faces while I was in the room that I was going to fail and that they weren't even trying to help me get to graduation! Ableist much to tell a disabled kid that they can never succeed in life!? And keep in mind that this school was considered the best in my district. Highly revered in my state as an amazing school..I learned SO much better while homeschooling because I was able to learn in the ways I needed and I was able to get the one-on-one learning that public and private schools don't do. The decision was about my well-being and not about politics. My siblings did great in either public or private school. I just didn't. .Also, even though my state doesn't have mandatory testing, my co-op always did the testing anyways. Most co-ops I have heard about around here do, actually. Homeschool parents DO want their kids to be learning. It's not a get-out-of-jail-free card. All the homeschool kids I know went through stricter learning than any mainstream school kid.

I homeschooled 5 children in the 90's and because of the closed schools in 2020, I volunteered to homeschool my grandson for Kindergarten.  By the time we finished the school year he was reading at a second grade level, was familiar with the 50 states, learned about the stock market daily, and was creating simple video games with arcademaker. Now in 2nd grade his national scores for reading are at 99 he also gets an A for every subject. He can spell better than most adults. He saw me using software to create early reading books and decided to use it to create his own books. He published an adorable coloring book 2 weeks ago and has already sold over 40 of them. I didn't even have to teach him to use the software. He figured it out. One of the biggest advantages to homeschooling is the the teacher is usually a parent or grandparent and is completely emotionally invested in the welfare of the child.

The fact that they thought she was being abused when she was at school but didn‚Äôt investigate say more about the DCPS than an indictment of homeschooling and the attitude of the legislature when speaking about this issue is the exact reason homeschoolers don‚Äôt trust the local or state or national government to act in homeschoolings best interest! And the history of the those governing bodies says they can‚Äôt be trusted.

I was homeschooled. I know people that it was great for and others that would have been much better in school. It really depends on the individual kid, the parents, and their educational system and social life. Upon going to university, I found out that my academic skills are at least average, maybe a little higher in some areas, so homeschooling did not hurt me in that regard. I think maybe I should have went to school just for social reasons, however, because I am so shy, I never wanted to join clubs or any of the social activities my homeschool friends and siblings were part of. My parents are very balanced and gave me the option to go to school but my social anxiety was so high, I never wanted to go. I guess I would have liked to have gone from a very early age but who knows, maybe I would still be extremely shy. .I am seeing now how it probably harmed my peers as a lot of my former homeschool friends turned out to be Trump loving, anti-vaxer, conspiracy theorists. .Homeschooling for religious reasons kind of sets off red flags for me although I am a religious person myself. It can work well for some families though and between Covid, shootings, bullies, and the frequent mistreatment of special needs children, the decision to homeschool is definitely understandable and may be the better option for some families.

I was homeschooled k-12. I had a great experience.  Many of my friends also had a good experiences. I believe I am a well-rounded individual who has friends that are liberal and conservative-from every walk of life. I believe homeschooling can be a successful thing for your family if done with thought and intentionality. I am married to a wonderful woman, have a baby on the way, doing great in my sales career. I have several siblings who are also doing great, my sister became a paralegal for one of the largest real estate law firms in our state. My brother got his degree in robotics, and now works for the city and their water department, in addition to him being technician for Blackhawk helicopters for the national guard. My homeschool graduate brother-in-law has a masters degree as a teacher- He teaches math and science at a local high school. One of my friends got a full ride scholarship to our state college for bio engineering at the age of 16, his brother also got a scholarship to the same state school. Not every homeschooler is a great success story, but most of the ones I know are. ..I have also worked with thousands of kids and teens from my community and surrounding areas. So many were falling through the cracks and not getting the attention or the education they needed. Many of them were literally failing classes- and then once Covid started I saw that number multiply. So my thought is before trying to come after homeschoolers, maybe those people should focus on improving the school situation.

I was homeschooled, however I was also grew up into a Houston homeschool group. Primarily the group did the extracurricular activities such as Art, Speech, and my favorite was Personal Education. My mother and a friend made this available, and our group shifted towards a special needs group. We had members that had autism and down syndrome. I as one of the most senior and integrated members of this group was put into a very interesting position. I knew the valuable contributions of this group, but I also knew at a subconscious level that I was being put into a echo chamber. Looking back now, I wish I had taken my moms advice to go straight from a middle school level into community college. Homeschooling can definitely be a burden and a boon, and the fact that I left my group at the high school level can only be described that I made a choice. This video may describe a majority of current homeschoolers, or it might not. I stick by the fact that my mothers choice to homeschool me was a boon, and not a burden to those I grew up with.

I guess I would have liked to have gone from a very early age but who knows, maybe I would still be extremely shy. .I am seeing now how it probably harmed my peers as a lot of my former homeschool friends turned out to be Trump loving, anti-vaxer, conspiracy theorists. .Homeschooling for religious reasons kind of sets off red flags for me although I am a religious person myself. It can work well for some families though and between Covid, shootings, bullies, and the frequent mistreatment of special needs children, the decision to homeschool is definitely understandable and may be the better option for some families.

I was homeschooled k-12. I had a great experience.  Many of my friends also had a good experiences. I believe I am a well-rounded individual who has friends that are liberal and conservative-from every walk of life. I believe homeschooling can be a successful thing for your family if done with thought and intentionality. I am married to a wonderful woman, have a baby on the way, doing great in my sales career. I have several siblings who are also doing great, my sister became a paralegal for one of the largest real estate law firms in our state. My brother got his degree in robotics, and now works for the city and their water department, in addition to him being technician for Blackhawk helicopters for the national guard. My homeschool graduate brother-in-law has a masters degree as a teacher- He teaches math and science at a local high school. One of my friends got a full ride scholarship to our state college for bio engineering at the age of 16, his brother also got a scholarship to the same state school. Not every homeschooler is a great success story, but most of the ones I know are. ..I have also worked with thousands of kids and teens from my community and surrounding areas. So many were falling through the cracks and not getting the attention or the education they needed. Many of them were literally failing classes- and then once Covid started I saw that number multiply. So my thought is before trying to come after homeschoolers, maybe those people should focus on improving the school situation.

I was homeschooled. I know people that it was great for and others that would have been much better in school. It really depends on the individual kid, the parents, and their educational system and social life. Upon going to university, I found out that my academic skills are at least average, maybe a little higher in some areas, so homeschooling did not hurt me in that regard. I think maybe I should have went to school just for social reasons, however, because I am so shy, I never wanted to join clubs or any of the social activities my homeschool friends and siblings were part of. My parents are very balanced and gave me the option to go to school but my social anxiety was so high, I never wanted to go. I'm extremely sympathetic to different types of learning because I understand not every child is going to do well in traditional schooling-I went to a very liberal private high school that was full of great ideas and teachers and far more diversity than my hometown. I'm thankful I was able to experience that and broaden my horizons, something I never could have done in my public school. That said, these people are unqualified and are doing this for insidious reasons. Everyone thinks teaching looks easy but it's really not and I feel sorry that these children are going to suffer in the future because they didn't get an education from qualified people and instead were fed propaganda by politically motivated adults acting in bad faith.

I started homeschooling my kids after an awful year of remote learning. It was so frustrating and my children suffered from it. We homeschooled and their grades got better. We joined a co-op last year and their grades and attitudes improved even more. They are more advanced now compared to other kids their same age and are not living with the anxiety they had when in public school. They are getting a more specialized education that is not politically or financially driven. They learn the truth of the worlds history and fundamentals that actually will help them be productive adults. You would think public schools would not mind having less kids so classrooms are not so over crowded. Teachers could focus more on their time with each student. .Homeschooling is not for everyone, but everyone I know that has homeschooled or is currently don‚Äôt regret it one bit.

I worked in Schools in poor rural communities, and I feel torn I saw awful teachers (not many but a handful at every school) who do not care much for their trade but were from well off families or were popular when they were in school (read connected).  My wife is a teacher, and well loved by her students and I must say she is AMAZING, some people are natural educators (think back to that fun teacher who really cared about their students...  yeah, I bet you can remember random knowledge from that class).  Standardized testing was meant to root out those underperforming educators however as I see it; standardized testing has only tied the hands of those good teachers and the crap teachers are still employed.  I don't have an answer, I just know that I take time to explain complex concepts to my children and try to get them interested... ever told a 10 year old about electrons spinning both directions (spin up and spin down) at the same time, until it has been observed at which time it takes only one direction and another electron somewhere else in the universe takes the other.... Yeah I don't understand it myself but my kid watched a dozen youtube videos because he was sure I was full of crap.... haha No easy answers, No one size fits all solutions but our education system is broken (don't think so? check out common core multiplication (lattice multiplication))
So happy about all the positive commenters! I love being a homeschool mom. I really appreciate all the parents, family members, etc. who take to time to do this important work.

My daughter taught 1st @ 2nd grade for a few years and I would come sometimes to provide some extra help.  It was very stressful.  There is always one child who is physical and disrupts the flow of the class.  Many of the kids just do not pay attention and are behind.  When she had her 1st child I moved in during the week and she would put her 4 month old in bed with me after she nursed her at 5.30am.  I of course loved it but my poor daughter was not happy leaving her all day.  She quit teaching after she turned two and was pregnant soon after with her 2nd baby.  She is now homeschooling a 5 and 8 year old.  It does not have anything to do with religion.  She likes being able to let them learn things they are interested in.  They do not use a computer for learning and both girls write well and are very expressive.  They have a group homeschool that meets twice a week which gives them other kids to play with although they have kids in the neighborhood to play with when they get home from school.  The 8 year old reads voraciously and I give them both books as gifts.  At the moment they do not do anything with the state...My son did homeschooling because he hated high school.  He ended up getting a GP at age 17 and was surprised at how easy the test was.  I know from my experiences that schools are dumbing kids down in many ways.

From some things I've been hearing about public schools, I think home schooling is a good alternative. If I had school age children, I think I would definitely consider home schooling. The things I've been hearing and seeing are not happening in all areas of the country, so I might also consider moving to a different area if I lived in one where those things might be going on.

I was in homeschool and charter schools periodically throughout my school years and graduated from a charter  high school. It was amazing. Now I‚Äôm charter schooling my kids and it amazing. They are HAPPY and thriving in school. My kids don‚Äôt come home sad or defeated. I‚Äôm so glad I have this opportunity and I hope everyone explores the idea!
I'm glad I went to public school. It saved me from my mom for at least 8 hours a day. It's insightful to see how & why people in the USA are homeschooling.

I'm currently homeschooling. It started with the pandemic but my kids score on G&T scale & some subjects at their grade level were too easy. The political stuff, the shootings, the state of our country, lack of quality education etc are all factors in the choice. There may come a day I put them back in public school. We try to do local homeschool meet ups for socialization. Homeschooling doesn't have to be expensive, either. It was actually the more affordable option in the meantime for our family. Non religious. My kids get to ask and learn about subjects they wouldn't even touch on in public school since everyone is on the same "track" and there's not much freedom/flexibility in a childs individual curiosity. And the schools in the area are over crowded and have a bad rating. For now, at least, at an elementary level, I can provide a better education for them.

I believe in homeschooling, but there needs to be a required curriculum (for the main 4 subjects). I also think there needs to be a requirement that the person teaching that curriculum is qualified to teach. There are way too many resources nowadays for a homeschool parent not to provide their children with a proper education. If homeschooling is done right, children will learn how to use their time efficiently, have more time for hobbies and family, and will have a 1:1 interaction they'd never get in a regular school.

I was in a failing school system in an area where being white was the minority. I know what it's like to attend schools without any resources. Some teachers get so burnt out they leave and others are crying behind closed doors but stay for the kids. ..I was not reaching my potential until I switched my junior year to an alternative program my school had just started. It was typically utilized by students who were trouble makers or not doing well. But there were a select group who attended that school for 3 hours a day online with a teacher who excelled in that environment. I ended up graduating more than a full year ahead of time - finishing my junior year in December. I went on to college and work out of Boston now but grew up in Ohio...Kids deserve funding and support. Teachers need it to survive and to teach those kids. We need to do better.
Hope the home school movement continues to grow

I was homeschooled growing up because we couldn't afford private school and was bullied by the kids in the neighborhood who I would go to public school with. We couldn't afford to move, so homeschooled it was. Luckily, my mom had been a teacher for 15+ years. I do think that parents of children who go to public school forget that they need to supplement their education at home, and that if you object to certain lessons you can voice that to the administration ahead of time and remove your child for a short time. They're still your children even when they're at school.

I grew up homeschooled up till high school.  And was in a homeschooling group.  I think homeschooling can be fantastic, I loved the freedom I had.  When I got to college I felt like it was going back to being homeschooled.  With that said, I find the piece odd because this isn't homeschooling its a loophole.  Like parents aren't teaching or have power, they are just sending them to a space they are comfortable with (and homeschool bubble is real).  For me, for certain classes I would go to a class ones a week, and then do my homework the rest of the week, like taking a piano class.  I do think homeschooling is great it sad to me that its tied to a Christian bubble space.

Open market competition in our educational system is totally justified and healthy.  Parents pulling their offspring out of public education is not what is destroying public schools.  Their policies and curriculum has already destroyed public education.  The only thing worse than destructive public school policies are parents who won't advocate for their own offspring, on their own sweat, tears and resources.

I was homeschooled through Florida Virtual School. I liked the flexibility of my schedule and how it allowed other activities as well as being fully accredited. I was able to take a lot of AP classes and even opt-in for just taking AP tests in a subject I studies. I got credit for AP Spanish and AP Physics through that, while also spending significantly less time on the subjects than if I was in school for an hour a day for a year for the same thing. It allowed me to learn at my pace, which was relatively accelerated and I was able to then take the time I saved and even start working and learning skills as well as making money.

I pulled both my kids out of public school and put them into private Christian school  I wish I‚Äôd have started them in private. My son went from a C student to an A student and the man he has become is amazing.  My daughter is flourishing.  The school doesn‚Äôt have all the bells and whistles of public schools, but the character development and classic education they get is second to none.
As a former teacher, I believe that anyone who truly cares about their kids should homeschool them. PERIOD.

I think this documentary was done really well showing both sides. On one hand I believe homeschool can be good for those who have the extra time and resources. But on the other hand I feel for public school a lot more. I went to public school and I feel I had a good education, importantly learned socialization, and have gone on to get my bachelors and become a nurse. My mother is a public school teacher and the resources they have to work with make it difficult. There's some big gaps in education with teaching finance and such but I don't think homeschooling is the answer

Thanks for this mini-documentary. I really appreciated the multi-dimensional reporting especially the public teacher‚Äôs point of view. Her passion for teaching was so evident. I do wonder if the Homeschool Association curriculum teaches service and greater community care. They seem to be talking about liberty, being weapons of war, battlefields and leaving to create their own communities. In my mind, that mindset of violence is troubling for civil society.
Homeschooling is the absolute best option there is! I love it.

I think this just sums up the failure of the public school system...  they talk about accreditation and licensing but here in Cali our public school kids are in last place in math and reading....it's an absolute tragedy

I was homeschooled from K-8, and though this shows some aspects of the homeschool community I think it‚Äôs missing a lot. We had a large group of homeschoolers in my area who were generally leftist or centrist, and made up of people who didn‚Äôt believe the academics in public school were strong enough. There are MANY people that homeschool that come from the left, not just right wing extremists. Where I currently live in Oregon, most homeschoolers are the nature loving hippie types!.People homeschool for so many reasons, and a lot of time there is a great community involved. This video shows such a narrow part of homeschool.

I pulled my kid out of school just over a year ago and am loving my homeschooling journey. Such an odd and dishonest take in this doco to paint homeschoolers as though they're these privileged families in society that are trying to take money away from the public school system. Instead of asking the education department to listen to why parents are taking their kids out of school they instead want to blame homeschoolers for public schools failing and being underfunded. Anyways, as intrigued as I was watching this, it was painful at times.  Like where is the outrage at kids (and teachers) being sexually and violently attacked at school..The education system is failing because it wants to indoctrinate children with values and ideals that parents don't agree with.  Also, as much as homes may not be a safe space for some children, let's also agree that schools may not a safe space for some kids also. There should be freedom to choose what is best for your family.
Homeschool child now sociologist here. Thanks for doing this story. It would be great with a follow up on the public school system.

I was homeschooled and I'd never go back. My sisters were homeschooled (same household, parents, etc.) and they hated it. Within the community there are pockets of borderline cults and there are also pockets of people who take their lives seriously and just want to do the best they can in society.
Wow if more (any color) families had moms like this mom there would not be the feeling of less than for any children/parents. She is amazing!!! Obviously, she is a loving mom.

Not all homeschool kids are weird or religious. Atheist here & my kids were homeschooled till college. We purchased our curriculum stuck to a schedule but traveled the world. They were in a lot of activities, little league, scouts, and other activities to meet friends. They both got very high ACT scores, scholarships, and got into their university of choice.

We pull our kids out, often dropping down to one income, often one substantially less than a school teacher's income!..Most of us live very frugally: we buy used, use everyday items and examples for teaching, we take advantage of every free resource that's available, we use used pencils and pens, things that people are giving away, partially used notebooks and supplies free or from thrift stores. And we don't get all emotional and weepy about it, either. These are OUR children and we will do whatever it takes to get them well educated, not indoctrinated!..Unlike public school teachers WE don't get paid to do this, we don't get benefits or pensions, and don't qualify for tax deductions for school supplies & expenses, but that teacher failed to mention THAT little perk!..Many of us use REAL books (REAL history, science, and other books and publications about what's really happening in the world, and visiting places where this stuff is applied), instead of textbooks for teaching, and or supplementing certain subjects with library books, or purchased them used. ..Many homeschoolers have developed curriculum that is usually better, and more in depth, and also MUCH more affordable than public school curriculums; but many buy used when possible. Public school curriculum is infamously overpriced and of demonstrably inferior academic quality...And the whole whiny party line about parents should try to work with them to change the public schools is a joke. When we get involved they complain, don't listen, argue with us, dismiss and marginalized us. Plenty of that's been seen on TV! So in the meantime they want us to give them access to our children while they continue to use a broken system...We have no say in curriculum selection, and academic quality is dumbed down to the lowest denominator. Besides, even the best teachers can't beat a system where they are handed crap textbooks that's all they're allowed to use, and can't work with kids according to their skills and abilities and levels!..Getting rid of bad teachers (like pedophiles!) is just about impossible, and now they sneak around behind our backs (conveniently NOT letting us know about certain topics they discuss and the organizations and people they bring in to promote them!) to make sure that we don't know when they are brainwashing our kids into other ideas. NO adult should be allowed to talk to another parents' minor children about sex and promote sexual ideologies without our knowledge, AGREEMENT, even ability to be there, or have live CC television so  we know what's being taught, and what's happening, at all times. To do otherwise is sexual grooming! Any school teacher who engages in such behavior should be immediately fired and prosecuted...Our children are penalized for for questioning what they're being taught, for resisting social conditioning, made fun of for their faith, and and there are always lawsuits about schools forbidding children from reading Bibles in school.

I find it comical that they show how public schools are failing kids and their response pretty much is, "yeah, that's because your kid isn't there. Please sacrifice all of your kids to the system in hopes that it'll get better."
I wasn't home-schooled, but I wish I was. More power to you Americans.

We pull our kids out, often dropping down to one income, often one substantially less than a school teacher's income!..Most of us live very frugally: we buy used, use everyday items and examples for teaching, we take advantage of every free resource that's available, we use used pencils and pens, things that people are giving away, partially used notebooks and supplies free or from thrift stores. And we don't get all emotional and weepy about it, either. These are OUR children and we will do whatever it takes to get them well educated, not indoctrinated!..Unlike public school teachers WE don't get paid to do this, we don't get benefits or pensions, and don't qualify for tax deductions for school supplies & expenses, but that teacher failed to mention THAT little perk!..Many of us use REAL books (REAL history, science, and other books and publications about what's really happening in the world, and visiting places where this stuff is applied), instead of textbooks for teaching, and or supplementing certain subjects with library books, or purchased them used. ..Many homeschoolers have developed curriculum that is usually better, and more in depth, and also MUCH more affordable than public school curriculums; but many buy used when possible. Public school curriculum is infamously overpriced and of demonstrably inferior academic quality...And the whole whiny party line about parents should try to work with them to change the public schools is a joke. When we get involved they complain, don't listen, argue with us, dismiss and marginalized us. Plenty of that's been seen on TV! So in the meantime they want us to give them access to our children while they continue to use a broken system...We have no say in curriculum selection, and academic quality is dumbed down to the lowest denominator. Besides, even the best teachers can't beat a system where they are handed crap textbooks that's all they're allowed to use, and can't work with kids according to their skills and abilities and levels!..Getting rid of bad teachers (like pedophiles!) is just about impossible, and now they sneak around behind our backs (conveniently NOT letting us know about certain topics they discuss and the organizations and people they bring in to promote them!) to make sure that we don't know when they are brainwashing our kids into other ideas. NO adult should be allowed to talk to another parents' minor children about sex and promote sexual ideologies without our knowledge, AGREEMENT, even ability to be there, or have live CC television so  we know what's being taught, and what's happening, at all times. To do otherwise is sexual grooming! Any school teacher who engages in such behavior should be immediately fired and prosecuted...Our children are penalized for for questioning what they're being taught, for resisting social conditioning, made fun of for their faith, and and there are always lawsuits about schools forbidding children from reading Bibles in school.
