I also like to add that our children should not be reliant on their peers as their main influence of how to relate, and socialize. They need to have quality, trusted adult influences as their primary influence so they aren‚Äôt wholly reliant on each other to learn these important lessons. When left on their own, they will form a hierarchy, and they will not stand firmly in their own opinions/morals/integrity if fitting in is more practical. We homeschool in PA, and it has one of the most strict homeschool legislation in the US. We are required to submit a notarized affidavit, health records (showing contact with mandatory reporters by the way of doctors to prevent masking child abuse), a syllabus that incorporates all of the state required subjects. At the years end, we must meet with an accredited evaluator with attendance, portfolio showing improvement upon the prior year, and we still are subjected to nationwide testing so the results for those are evaluated as well. We still pay property taxes, and the only resources we get are access to our local museum. Considering what we pay into our district, it I would at least expect the children attending school to have everything that they need for success. Instead we have one of the worst districts in the country.
The only thing my kids would miss if they were homeschooled is interaction with other kids. Education must take place at home FIRST and FOREMOST.

I started homeschooling 2 years ago. The local public school here has some pretty extreme behavior. My son's then 3rd grade teacher took his lunch away and told him if he didn't pray with the class, he wasn't going to eat and that he may not pray at home, but while he was in her class, he would pray. The superintendant's answer was to put my son in the hallway away from the students while they prayed. We once again complained to the school board and they became very belligerent and responded, "well, what do you want us to do?". I don't know, let my son eat in peace? We took both our children out of school and are homeschooling now.

Thank you Vice for never missing an opportunity to politicize something.  The idea that parents in control of their own children's education is in any way a negative is a disservice to all children.  It would be great to see a story and not have any idea what the host or network personal stances were.  I stumbled upon this story with some optimism and interest and now remember why so many were critical of Vice in the way they shape stories and narratives.  There's only one reason any organization would do this.

Imagine just for a moment black, asian, hispanic/latino and native/indigenous parents saying in a open school board forum they did not want their kids learning about white people. How well would that translate you think?

Religious exposure is also indoctrination, however, outdoor concept and being more in touch with nature is what our children are missing the most. We aren't supposed to lock our kids in four walls for the entire day and not let them explore, that's not how humans evolved. We are explorers, we learn through curiosity.

Would be nice if they had reviewed the statistics around home-schooled children. How do they fare in standardized testing or in college?  We have been schooling our children since 2009 because we can simply provide a better education than the public schools we've looked at. Evidence to back up that claim? My children consistently score at the highest levels in standardized tests. One of my children will have her associates degree before she graduates from high school.  I think we're doing okay. As for asking our children what they want - do parents of public-schooled children ask their children if they would prefer to be home schooled,  and then support that choice?

I was homeschooled and my parents still had to pay a school tax. When I started working at 16, I had to pay a school tax. Now that I'm an adult, I'll be homeschooling my daughter, but my husband and I still pay school taxes. Every single person who is employed in our state has a portion of their paychecks going to the schools, whether they attended or not. The schools still get money regardless of attendance. The current system of teaching is what is failing, not the schools themselves. It's an outdated system that hasn't been updated in over a century. It's pretty obvious that batch education is ineffective and that one-on-one teaching will always be better...I also want to mention that homeschooling in my state is extremely regulated. I'm in a blue state and they do not like homeschooling so they make it a very difficult process. There is a lot of paperwork, proof of education, and teacher evaluations starting at age 6 (thanks to Covid, they lowered the age from 8). It's a huge infringement on my freedom and I understand that they are trying to prevent people from abusing the system, but the good parents always get punished in the process. The amount of regulation has discouraged many parents from doing it, which is incredibly unfortunate.

Unfortunately we need parental involvement for a strong public education system and the extreme policies going in place and the safety issues are driving involved parents away.

I have no student debt & I've learned that I can go just as far with a GED as I could have all of my friends who have 2 & 3 degrees and can't have families bc of debt.

I am a student going into early childhood education. I've worked in a preschool classroom and with kids of all ages since I was a teenager. I'm about as far from conservative as a person can get. I would homeschool my future kids in a heartbeat. Certainly not for religious reasons, and certainly not because of things like Covid regulations in schools, but because I believe the way we educate our kids in this country is broken, and will take years to even come close to fixing. Kids deserve to be outside. They deserve time for unstructured, open-ended, independent and group play. They deserve one-on-one attention from adults. They deserve to explore their interests and work at their own pace. I don't see much of any of that happening in our public schools.

So many reasons to homeschool! Yes our faith and what we value  is one of them, but beyond that, I want my kids to have an education catered to the way they learn and that provides them with time in the day to delve deeper into the topics that interest them (maps currently for my second grader), and to have time to shadow or experience career interests in HS before having to pay for a college major. Beyond that, I don't want my kids to be overburdened by too many things going on and too much homework like I was with private school or too many sports like my husband. Being in the home environment  it's my hope that they also learn how to "adult" by being around when I do laundry, taxes, grocery shop, or hubby cooks...There are so many things to learn and when so many schools in my state don't even have a single student who is at grade level for reading or math, I'm certainly not going to trust them with my children. (It's not for lack of funding, some of these schools are spending $20,000+/student while schools with much lower funding have students doing better.)

How else can you fully pursue passions, be outside in nature multiple hours a day, interests and extra curriculars when you are trapped by a school schedule!? .We LOVE the freedom and flexibility and traveling....homeschooling is FREEDOM!

I have homeschooled for three years, initially due to the pandemic and non-existent public school resources at the time.  Our child is performing well above grade level and is confident, curious, and skilled.  It has been the most rewarding endeavor of my life to date, bar none.  Let me be clear: there is enormous personal sacrifice.  If you homeschool you must have the character to be completely different and always swim upstream.  I receive no income and have to purchase all materials, but I have teaching skill and drive so scaffolding, introducing topics, and reinforcing skills sets is a cinch to me.  Also, I am pushed to the margins socially.  People truly do not understand what it is that I do.  However, they are always quick to remark how well-behaved our kid is, and how smart.  I wish I could get this across to other parents: you have to show up and put in the time or your kid will turn in to someone you don't like and can't recognize, i.e. someone raised by the state.  You have to ask about the conditioning you received in public school and if you are prepared to project that same conditioning onto your offspring, i.e. outgrouping, bullying, intellectual stifling.   Unfortunately, some parents cant or won't home educate because of societal pressure.  You have to ask yourself, what can I live with?  What can I live without?  It takes a level of bravery and grit most people aren't prepared for.  Also, wages are far too low to make most of this possible for most people who have kids and also work, anyway.  I get that.  Another major issue is devaluation of home-based work.  If full-time parents were actually paid for their job, you would see a lot more homeschooling take place.  Parents would get to spend more time with their kids, and post-pandemic we've already seen a clear shift to workers preferring home-based employment.  .Now, our kid is requesting attendance at public school because she doesn't have any siblings and is ready for more socialization.  I am terrified the schools will brutally disappoint us...again.  The threat of gun violence alone should be enough to terrify any parent.  We grilled the current school on their response practices and did research about the threat of violence in our area.  It does little to assure me of any level of safety.  Also, we already tried this reluctantly last fall in another community before promptly removing our kid again and let's just say the professional misbehavior on the part of the staff was appalling beyond belief.  The principal stated, "I'm sorry, this should never have happened." Never in a million years was I prepared for the teacher misbehavior I encountered.  Currently, our schools are a dumpster fire, just like every other cultural institution.

There were multiple stories in this - the title is misleading. Amber Johnston, the black homeschooling mum demonstrated a great example of a healthy, typical approach of homeschooling ie wanting choice, the best for their kids, encouraging open rational thinking, however, she didn't have power herself or even collectively with like minded homeschoolers. By necessity she had to sign up to HDSLA for protection, not because it reflected her beliefs. The majority of this episode appeared to actually focus on right wing religious indoctrination to create a future fundamentalist state, steam rolling over legislation that sounds like it could actually help stop abuse towards children. A better title for this episode would have been: Religious Fundamentalists Recruiting Child Soldiers.

I home schooled my children.  One has a masters degree and the other a Ph.D.  I don't have a degree, but I was an honors student.  I think the best way to regulate homeschooling is to require annual standardized testing among a choice of major tests and to require parents and children to be part of a group that meets at least biweekly and the state should send a nurse to teach about recognizing signs and risk factors of negligence and abuse and require all parents in the group to be mandatory reporters of abuse and negligence.  I had very bad experiences in the public schools.  I would have preferred to have sent my children to a good quality Christian school, but I couldn't afford it.  Fortunately, our homeschool group offered group classes with mothers who had knowledge in various fields, such as one with a masters in biology.  When my children turned 14, I started them in part time community college classes.  My son got his bachelor's degree before his 19th birthday.

my son came home from school back in the 1990s and said flat out i am not going back to school it a total joke,(he was in junior high) so i sat down with him and said OK explain to me why. He made it clear, I spend 8 minutes transferring from one class to the next, it takes the teacher 10 to 15 minutes to take control of the class before they can start teaching and then the class becomes unruly 10 minutes later which takes the teach another 10 minutes to control so out of the 50 minutes allowed for the class we get maybe 10 min of actual learning. So I talked to a friend of mind who was home schooling (which was very controversial at the time, as the state took his kids away from him for a short period of time. the state calmed he could not home school and his kids were delinquent in going to school as the public school system was loosing money when he kids did not attend. this whole mess went to court and the state lost.)(Colorado by the way) we decided to home school. the only problem at that time and it may still be, is that most home school books you could buy at that time were very heavily based on religion. I do not think religion should be involved in teaching. so I had to really search for material to use. Home schooling is hard to do. but it can be done. My son went on to collage and graduated with very high honors.  The one thing I must stress is your child needs outside activities to help them learn to socialize, voluntary civic activities, boy scouts etc... they must be able to interact with there peers.

The public teacher crying about putting her new bday books back was a bit over the top. Empower yourself & go to the library. You can check it out for free, like many homeschooling families that have ‚Äòjumped ship‚Äô do. (Granted, you may have to wait a few weeks.) That is one public resource that many more folks should take advantage of!

I also love learning law.  But, I‚Äôm not that good at teaching.  I get frustrated when people don‚Äôt understand math when I‚Äôm teaching them.  Math was easy for me so I don‚Äôt understand how to help children that are struggling ‚Ä¶. I often go to YouTube and see how others explain the same topic or find a way to teach students who are having a hard time grasping a concept.  I am learning HOW to Teach!!!   I think that knowing how to teach is important...I have a sister who is so good at teaching that all children love learning from her ‚Ä¶ even my own children!  It‚Äôs not to say that my children don‚Äôt learn from me, it‚Äôs just that some people are natural teachers and good with Children like my sister.  .I want to homeschool my children, but I do think I have the patience to homeschool them 100% of the time, plus I am a single mother and the sole provider for my children.  So, I supplement my children‚Äôs learning with my knowledge and teaching them and getting tutors and effective programs for them.  ..I love learning and I believe my children can see this.  I also always tell my children that they shouldn‚Äôt let school get in their way of learning.  I tell my children to find what they are good at or like and become expert or professional in that.  I also tell them to learn from successful people that are doing what you want to do as that‚Äôs the best way to learn efficiently and efficiently!

There‚Äôs a difference between being critical as a journalist and twisting the narrative considerably through what seems like healthy criticism but is actually just the manipulation of truth through pointed but overly simplifying questions and the cherry picking of responses in the editing process. The media establishment gets the last word, naturally, but, in Vice‚Äôs case, should be much more careful not to swing the message one way or another. Of course, the assumption of some narratives is necessary to tell any story, and there are many angles which are both critical and impartial, but some are not and are instead wolves in sheep‚Äôs clothing - the wolf, at best, being a wolf of bad journalism and at worst a wolf of blood-thirst. The direction in which the narrative is pushed is also highly sensitive to the topic; in some cases one attitude and style of questioning will prove to show journalistic integrity while, in another case, that same attitude and style of questioning will alter the truth dramatically. It‚Äôs important for a news company to discern the many nuances of this fact‚Ä¶ but what do I know, I haven‚Äôt even finished the video.

I think while some of the arguments against homeschooling are thought provoking, they are inherently wrong. The world is unfair. Not every parent loves their child, not every child is given every opportunity they need or deserve. Some children are abused at home, should we get rid of homes and families? Some children are abused at schools, should we get rid of schools? Some people drive intoxicated, should we get rid of all cars to make life fair? No. Every child will get a different education no matter what you do, even if you gave everyone the exact same thing they would still not get the same test scores. Life is unfair, uneven, unequal, and you will never be able to make it so. And I don't think you should. To those who say you should put your kids in a failing public school where...what was the stat they used? Only 1 in 4 juniors in hs were proficient in science or math or something? So I should put my kid in the failing school because it's not fair to someone else? That's not how the world works. That's an unhealthy relationship, a toxic relationship. We're not good for you, but you need to stay cause I need you. Fix the public schools, sure...but also let the homeschoolers have their own tax dollars to use to educate their children as they see fit (parents in the public school, their tax dollars go to public education, they are choosing that, fair yes?). You don't have to control everything.....you can't. Accept the truth that there will always be successful people and people who fall behind, no matter what you do

I taught middle school.  We had a large diversity of students, from well-to-do families to those who lived in poverty.  From children who benefitted from being exposed to the culture at large, to those who never had a book read to them at home...  We taught all of them.  The teachers I worked with were extremely hard working, dedicated, and loved teaching.  It was not a cushy job and was often quite stressful.  Watching this youtube, these children have the benefit of having parents with the time and ability to give their children complete attention.  For most of us, that arrangement is more than we are able to provide.  Also, it appears that many of these homeschoolers are not in pubic school because of their parent's religious beliefs that I fear they want to impose in our public schools.  This is totally unacceptable to me.  This country has a separation of church and state in our constitution, we are NOT a Christian nation.  Homeschooling allows them that choice, but their attempt to force their beliefs into our public schools is highly problematic to the public at large.

There‚Äôs a difference between being critical as a journalist and twisting the narrative considerably through what seems like healthy criticism but is actually just the manipulation of truth through pointed but overly simplifying questions and the cherry picking of responses in the editing process. The media establishment gets the last word, naturally, but, in Vice‚Äôs case, should be much more careful not to swing the message one way or another. Of course, the assumption of some narratives is necessary to tell any story, and there are many angles which are both critical and impartial, but some are not and are instead wolves in sheep‚Äôs clothing - the wolf, at best, being a wolf of bad journalism and at worst a wolf of blood-thirst. The direction in which the narrative is pushed is also highly sensitive to the topic; in some cases one attitude and style of questioning will prove to show journalistic integrity while, in another case, that same attitude and style of questioning will alter the truth dramatically. It‚Äôs important for a news company to discern the many nuances of this fact‚Ä¶ but what do I know, I haven‚Äôt even finished the video.

I taught middle school.  We had a large diversity of students, from well-to-do families to those who lived in poverty.  From children who benefitted from being exposed to the culture at large, to those who never had a book read to them at home...  We taught all of them.  The teachers I worked with were extremely hard working, dedicated, and loved teaching.  It was not a cushy job and was often quite stressful.  Watching this youtube, these children have the benefit of having parents with the time and ability to give their children complete attention.  For most of us, that arrangement is more than we are able to provide.  Also, it appears that many of these homeschoolers are not in pubic school because of their parent's religious beliefs that I fear they want to impose in our public schools.  This is totally unacceptable to me.  This country has a separation of church and state in our constitution, we are NOT a Christian nation.  Homeschooling allows them that choice, but their attempt to force their beliefs into our public schools is highly problematic to the public at large.

I taught middle school.  We had a large diversity of students, from well-to-do families to those who lived in poverty.  From children who benefitted from being exposed to the culture at large, to those who never had a book read to them at home...  We taught all of them.  The teachers I worked with were extremely hard working, dedicated, and loved teaching.  It was not a cushy job and was often quite stressful.  Watching this youtube, these children have the benefit of having parents with the time and ability to give their children complete attention.  For most of us, that arrangement is more than we are able to provide.  Also, it appears that many of these homeschoolers are not in pubic school because of their parent's religious beliefs that I fear they want to impose in our public schools.  This is totally unacceptable to me.  This country has a separation of church and state in our constitution, we are NOT a Christian nation.  Homeschooling allows them that choice, but their attempt to force their beliefs into our public schools is highly problematic to the public at large.
This is not a home school, it's just a private school.

There‚Äôs a difference between being critical as a journalist and twisting the narrative considerably through what seems like healthy criticism but is actually just the manipulation of truth through pointed but overly simplifying questions and the cherry picking of responses in the editing process. The media establishment gets the last word, naturally, but, in Vice‚Äôs case, should be much more careful not to swing the message one way or another. Of course, the assumption of some narratives is necessary to tell any story, and there are many angles which are both critical and impartial, but some are not and are instead wolves in sheep‚Äôs clothing - the wolf, at best, being a wolf of bad journalism and at worst a wolf of blood-thirst. The direction in which the narrative is pushed is also highly sensitive to the topic; in some cases one attitude and style of questioning will prove to show journalistic integrity while, in another case, that same attitude and style of questioning will alter the truth dramatically. It‚Äôs important for a news company to discern the many nuances of this fact‚Ä¶ but what do I know, I haven‚Äôt even finished the video.

There‚Äôs a difference between being critical as a journalist and twisting the narrative considerably through what seems like healthy criticism but is actually just the manipulation of truth through pointed but overly simplifying questions and the cherry picking of responses in the editing process. The media establishment gets the last word, naturally, but, in Vice‚Äôs case, should be much more careful not to swing the message one way or another. Of course, the assumption of some narratives is necessary to tell any story, and there are many angles which are both critical and impartial, but some are not and are instead wolves in sheep‚Äôs clothing - the wolf, at best, being a wolf of bad journalism and at worst a wolf of blood-thirst. The direction in which the narrative is pushed is also highly sensitive to the topic; in some cases one attitude and style of questioning will prove to show journalistic integrity while, in another case, that same attitude and style of questioning will alter the truth dramatically. It‚Äôs important for a news company to discern the many nuances of this fact‚Ä¶ but what do I know, I haven‚Äôt even finished the video.

I taught middle school.  We had a large diversity of students, from well-to-do families to those who lived in poverty.  From children who benefitted from being exposed to the culture at large, to those who never had a book read to them at home...  We taught all of them.  The teachers I worked with were extremely hard working, dedicated, and loved teaching.  It was not a cushy job and was often quite stressful.  Watching this youtube, these children have the benefit of having parents with the time and ability to give their children complete attention.  For most of us, that arrangement is more than we are able to provide.  Also, it appears that many of these homeschoolers are not in pubic school because of their parent's religious beliefs that I fear they want to impose in our public schools.  This is totally unacceptable to me.  This country has a separation of church and state in our constitution, we are NOT a Christian nation.  Homeschooling allows them that choice, but their attempt to force their beliefs into our public schools is highly problematic to the public at large.

There's pros & cons of homeschooling. Let's not sugarcoat the educational system. Remember folks not every parent has the knowledge, patience & time to teach their own children. When a working couple have two children, a parent can have very little discretionary money for oneself. Whatever the children need is the priority. There are wrong reasons for homeschooling such as theocratic policy and fascist politics, which often overlap. Sometimes, the school environments are too violent and home schooling would be the better option. That said, the minimum requirement of a family is to provide safety. When that requirement is not met, then, for some children, school can represent a safer option, regardless of educational considerations. Yet, as mentioned in these comments, there are some parents who are equipped  intellectually and emotionally to provide their children a better learning environment than can public school. I was not home schooled, but my Yale graduated father provided me with more education than my public schooling ever did, and he did so with loving care; reading to us, copious subjects, hands on field and travel. I am forever indebted to his dedication.

I homeschool because I refuse to let the public school system decide what is and is not important to teach my child. We're not going to tip-toe around confronting subjects that shed light on the darker parts of American history. We're not going to avoid certain books for the same reason. In fact, if a book is on a ban list in some of these backwards states, it goes without saying my child will read it. We're not going to focus solely on Algebra, Geometry, and Calculus whilst ignoring curriculum that teaches basic life principles like budgeting, tax, and law. She's going to learn about first aid, physical and mental health, she's going to spend more time outside than stuck in a classroom. Is my motivation for homeschooling political? To some degree, yes, because I want my kid to go into the world and create a positive change. I want her to learn how to examine information critically and form her own opinions, not just how to bubble in the right answer on a spreadsheet. In my opinion, you ought to do a follow up video discussing the other side.

Homeschooling can give your kid a leg up over public schooled kids, or it can turn into a horror story (though in all fairness there are plenty of public school horror stories of uneducated 18 year olds too)...Either way, whether for net good or for net ill, the homeschooling movement is largely a consequence of the failure of public schools on two fronts: ..First, they took the reasonable "Public schools shouldn't be Christian religious schools" and extrapolated from there to the quite unreasonable "We owe no substantive accommodations or compromises to religious communities that might be harmed by the curriculum we plan to teach". Predictably you had millions of Evangelical parents who responded by dropping out of the system altogether....Second, they integrated students from lower and middle income households (yes, and with an obvious racial association) without holding all students to the level of discipline that middle class households demand. If there's anything you can reliably expect from 99.99% of middle class parents, it's that they'll freak out if they get the slightest sense that their kids are spending hours every day in a dangerous environment.

Regarding the budgetary discussion, consider that homeschool parents still pay state and local taxes‚Ä¶really on behalf of other people‚Äôs children. The crying teacher‚Äôs tears are genuine, has been led to believe her challenges are the fault of homeschool families. I would argue that since the tax revenue is unaffected, the responsibility for the teacher‚Äôs challenges lies on the people controlling the budget.

looking back i wish i was homeschooled. i was horribly bullied from a young age for being gay (despite not realizing until i was 18 that i was gay...) and i was also way ahead of my peers in terms of intelligence but held back from my full potential because my parents wanted me to be "normal" and not have a complex. i found public school (graduated 2007) to be painfully boring, full of meaningless busywork and waiting for the slower kids to get the concepts being taught, not to mention the disruptive kids constantly making school miserable for everyone else. i do believe there should be standards though across the board as to what concepts are being taught and at what ages so that the general public is all on the same page and not confusing opinions for facts. too much freedom and kids will be taught that the earth is flat and jesus rode on dinosaurs... which is child abuse in the form of denying them an education. another issue i take with public schools (i have no experience with charter or private) is that they seem designed to warehouse kids and teach them to be good little wage slaves who are obedient and know just enough to do their jobs but not too much to question why theyre doing it in the first place. that frustrated me the most about school besides the bullying which has been a lifelong trauma for me that might of been avoided had i been homeschooled. also i wanna add i went to a good school, in a good district, full of mostly rich kids. and it still sucked.

34:21 A tip for Tess Jackson...There was a school, I taught 7 through 9th grades (Swedish and German, two parallel classes for each grade) back in autumn of 95. Most young adults there (and a colleague from back then, who was a regular teacher with a fixed contract shares my distaste for calling teens "children") were, as you said, "left behind" .....There was a young man, who was so bored with math, that for a rectangular door with a round window hole (calculate surface to paint) he actually multiplied pi with the larger dimensions, those of the door, and I voted to get him less hours in school, and most of the week as an apprentice to a cook. He loved cooking. It's an obviously useful and up there (yes, it's tourist country) lucrative trade. I didn't push him forward by getting more resources for his school (which was for that time also mine), I pushed him forward by helping to opt him out of that school...And _that_ push forward can be obtained for the young adults you care about as well (is seventh grade starting the year they have their thirteenth birthday in US as well, or not? With first grade at age five, the seventhgraders would still be children).

I've seen two sides of this with old acquaintances. Some of the kids who were home schooled are fine, they're learning at an appropriate level and absorbing knowledge like a sponge... And of the flip side of things, I've got a few who... are 14-17 years old and can't read above an elementary level. Those kids... those poor kids are going to have it ROUGH.

I'm very grateful that I had good public schools growing up. That said, as a Black woman in America, being in an environment where you can count on one hand the number of people who look like you gets old. I think I only had one Black teacher for a core subject (i.e. math, science, etc. not art, music, gym... no disrespect to those teachers though!) during my whole K-12 career. Many of us learn very quickly that Black people aren't in charge and that our history warrants just a few weeks of focus a year. (And even then, it apparently started and ended in the 1960s). It makes you feel unimportant as a kid. I think this has more of an impact that people realize. I felt 100% academically prepared in college and grad school, but I'm still learning/unlearning so much socially as an adult. I don't yet have any children, but if I do, this will certainly be a factor in deciding how to educate them.

2009 I homeschooled my last child because between an addicted older child, parent in their 90's, no support from my child's father, the need to work full time, I thought that the free K12 courses would allow me to blend his education into my work from home job. 3 of my kids got snatched by the state one year on some trumped-up charges.  The judge in charge of the case did NOT follow state law but the 2 attorneys who supposedly worked for me both said the judge did not have to follow the law!  He could basically do whatever he wanted in his court.  I was not allowed (can you believe that?!?) to present state laws or scientific studies refuting the judges claims to the court.  ..One thing I did early on, was I listened to all the people claiming my kids lacked social skills & academic skills, then I said, "Ok!  Let's test that!"  They had already passed medical exams and shown excellent fitness (contrary to the claims that they lacked it from not getting organized sports -they didn't consider martial arts, nature skills & swordplay to be "organized?")  I cited EVERY SINGLE CLAIM against my kids and suggested they be tested.  ..After 3 months in public schools ALL their teachers said they were good students and that they showed no problems interacting with either adults or students.  They were tested using all the standardized tests available in the state (I recommended some from Texas, but they declined those).  I scolded one of my kids because on one of her tests she "only" scored 90%.  Most tests placed my kids in the 93-99% range.  After testing my older daughter was skipped ahead a grade in mathematics. He demanded an entire year of lesson plans for each child to include readings & questions, exams, etc.  NOTE: ZERO public school teachers must do that...There is extreme hostility to homeschooling by leftists who believe Christian parents have no right to educate their own children!

This is what you need to educate your children at home. A governess.  A Governess woman employed as a private tutor, who teaches and trains a child or children in their home. A governess often lives in the same residence as the children she is teaching. In contrast to a nanny, the primary role of a governess is teaching, rather than meeting the physical needs of children; hence a governess is usually in charge of school-aged children, rather than babies..The position of governess used to be common in affluent European families before the First World War, especially in the countryside where no suitable school existed nearby and when parents preferred to educate their children at home rather than send them away to boarding school for months at a time, and varied across time and countries. Governesses were usually in charge of girls and younger boys. When a boy was old enough, he left his governess for a tutor or a school..These people are just poor.

I taught middle school.  We had a large diversity of students, from well-to-do families to those who lived in poverty.  From children who benefitted from being exposed to the culture at large, to those who never had a book read to them at home...  We taught all of them.  The teachers I worked with were extremely hard working, dedicated, and loved teaching.  It was not a cushy job and was often quite stressful.  Watching this youtube, these children have the benefit of having parents with the time and ability to give their children complete attention.  For most of us, that arrangement is more than we are able to provide.  Also, it appears that many of these homeschoolers are not in pubic school because of their parent's religious beliefs that I fear they want to impose in our public schools.  This is totally unacceptable to me.  This country has a separation of church and state in our constitution, we are NOT a Christian nation.  Homeschooling allows them that choice, but their attempt to force their beliefs into our public schools is highly problematic to the public at large.

Not every parent loves their child, not every child is given every opportunity they need or deserve. Some children are abused at home, should we get rid of homes and families? Some children are abused at schools, should we get rid of schools? Some people drive intoxicated, should we get rid of all cars to make life fair? Life is unfair, uneven, unequal, and you will never be able to make it so. And I don't think you should. So I should put my kid in the failing school because it's not fair to someone else? That's not how the world works. That's an unhealthy relationship, a toxic relationship. We're not good for you, but you need to stay cause I need you. Fix the public schools, sure...but also let the homeschoolers have their own tax dollars to use to educate their children as they see fit (parents in the public school, their tax dollars go to public education, they are choosing that, fair yes?). You don't have to control everything.....you can't. Accept the truth that there will always be successful people and people who fall behind, no matter what you do

I taught middle school.  We had a large diversity of students, from well-to-do families to those who lived in poverty.  From children who benefitted from being exposed to the culture at large, to those who never had a book read to them at home...  We taught all of them.  The teachers I worked with were extremely hard working, dedicated, and loved teaching.  It was not a cushy job and was often quite stressful.  Watching this youtube, these children have the benefit of having parents with the time and ability to give their children complete attention.  For most of us, that arrangement is more than we are able to provide.  Also, it appears that many of these homeschoolers are not in pubic school because of their parent's religious beliefs that I fear they want to impose in our public schools.  This is totally unacceptable to me.  This country has a separation of church and state in our constitution, we are NOT a Christian nation.  Homeschooling allows them that choice, but their attempt to force their beliefs into our public schools is highly problematic to the public at large.
This is not a home school, it's just a private school.

There‚Äôs a difference between being critical as a journalist and twisting the narrative considerably through what seems like healthy criticism but is actually just the manipulation of truth through pointed but overly simplifying questions and the cherry picking of responses in the editing process. The media establishment gets the last word, naturally, but, in Vice‚Äôs case, should be much more careful not to swing the message one way or another. Of course, the assumption of some narratives is necessary to tell any story, and there are many angles which are both critical and impartial, but some are not and are instead wolves in sheep‚Äôs clothing - the wolf, at best, being a wolf of bad journalism and at worst a wolf of blood-thirst. The direction in which the narrative is pushed is also highly sensitive to the topic; in some cases one attitude and style of questioning will prove to show journalistic integrity while, in another case, that same attitude and style of questioning will alter the truth dramatically. It‚Äôs important for a news company to discern the many nuances of this fact‚Ä¶ but what do I know, I haven‚Äôt even finished the video.
